nodes.text: Conventional cost-benefit analysis presumes ex-ante cost and benefit estimates are accurate and unbiased, and the paper tests whether this assumption holds for public investments

Dataset and measurement method: assembled the largest dataset of its kind with 2,062 public investment projects (eight investment types, 104 countries, 1927-2013); cost overrun = actual/estimated cost; benefit overrun = actual/estimated first-year benefits

Data collection details and quality control: data mined from accounts, audits, studies; only documentary-supported data included; 25% of cost and 50% of benefit data rejected for quality; subsample of 327 projects has both cost and benefit overruns
Limitation and selection concerns: data availability likely biases sample toward better-performing projects and survival/selection bias may underrepresent poorly performing projects

Statistical finding: cost estimates are highly inaccurate and biased with average cost overruns (actual/estimated) > 1, fat right tails, extreme skewness and kurtosis, and Wilcoxon test rejecting symmetry around one at p<0.0001

Statistical finding: benefit estimates are inaccurate and biased with average benefit overruns often < 1 (benefit shortfalls), skewed and fat-tailed distributions, and Wilcoxon test rejecting symmetry at p<0.001

Result: cost underestimation and benefit overestimation compound for the average investment rather than cancelling out; Mann-Whitney test rejects hypothesis that cost and benefit errors balance (p<0.0001)

Quantitative magnitudes: average cost overruns vary by type (roads 24% to dams 85% average), weighted total average cost overrun about 1.39-1.43; weighted total average benefit overrun about 0.94 (unweighted 0.83)
Economic consequence: conventional ex-ante benefit-cost ratios are overestimated by roughly 50 to 200 percent depending on investment type, implying systematic overstatement of net benefits

Robustness: findings hold across conventional and Bayesian statistical tests and across subsamples, investment types, geographies, and time periods, indicating a universal pattern of inaccuracy and bias

Behavioral explanation: root causes of systematic cost underestimation and benefit overestimation are planner behavior including optimism bias, planning fallacy, overconfidence, and strategic misrepresentation rather than solely technical causes like geology or delays

Conclusion: the 'cost-benefit fallacy' exists—practitioners behave as if forecasts are accurate when they are systematically biased—leading cost-benefit analysis as practiced to misinform decisions and cause resource misallocation

Measurement assumption and proxy limitation: benefits proxied by first-year benefits (convention) because life-cycle benefits rarely available; first-year benefits correlate with later years but wider benefits and shadow pricing are often omitted
Policy recommendation 1: systematic and precise de-biasing of forecasts using the outside view and reference class forecasting based on empirical distributional information from past projects

Policy recommendations 2-4: introduce skin-in-the-game for forecasters, require independent audits separated from political influence, and adapt cost-benefit practice to democratic decision making rather than purely technocratic top-down use

Conclusion and implication: adopting behavioral de-biasing methods, incentives, audits, and democratic integration can make cost-benefit analysis useful again, but the cost-benefit fallacy is deep-rooted and difficult to eliminate
